article.headline: Memphis 64, Houston 48
article.story: MEMPHIS, Tenn. (AP)-- Memphis ran away from Houston early, which wasn't too difficult. The Cougars' offense was stuck at the starting gate. Sean Banks scored 18 points and Memphis held Houston to 10 first-half points en route to a 64-48 victory Saturday night. "It was a great defensive effort," Memphis coach John Calipari said. "We really had fresh legs and energy. We didn't shoot it particularly well, but I'm not worried about that. This is the third game this year we shot in the mid-30s and won." Banks connected on 6 of 13 shots as Memphis (12-4, 3-2 Conference USA) broke the game open early. The Tigers' lead reached double digits after 13 minutes of play and stayed there the rest of the night. Rodney Carney added 14 points for Memphis, and Antonio Burks scored 12. The Cougars (7-9, 1-4) were led by Marcus Oliver's 15 points. Lanny Smith scored 11. Both teams were sloppy and neither shot well, both connecting on 36 percent from the floor. Memphis spent much of the night launching 3s over Houston's tightly packed zone. "If that's what they're giving you, and they are wide open, you've got to shoot them," Calipari said. "We've got a couple of guys right now that just can't make them." Memphis controlled the boards 44-31, led by 13 from Ivan Lopez. The Tigers shot just 31 percent in the first half and still led by 21 points. That's because the first period was a nightmare for Houston. The Cougars hit only five field goals, shot 19 percent, never got to the free throw line and were outrebounded 29-16. The Tigers led 31-10 at the break. Smith and fellow guard Andre Owens were a combined 1-of-14 from the field in the half. Houston coach Ray McCallum said he couldn't recall going through a period like it. "I thought we got after them defensively, but we couldn't score," McCallum said. "I thought we had some pretty good looks. You've got to give (the Tigers) credit for doing a job on our guards." Meanwhile, Memphis was firing over the Houston zone with only slightly better success. Of the Tigers' 32 first-half field goal attempts, 20 were 3-point tries. Six went in. For the game the Tigers were 10 of 35 from outside. Houston doubled its first-half point total within five minutes of play in the second half, and still the Cougars never got closer than 15 points. The lone bright spot was shooting 52 percent over the final 20 minutes. "You keep playing and you keep fighting and the shots are going to fall," McCallum said. "You can say Memphis let up, but from our standpoint, the ball moved, our turnovers went down, we shot (52 percent), and we were able to get the ball inside and be effective."
